questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:

I was born into a middle-class Tamil family in the island town of Rameswaram in the erstwhile Madras State. My father, Jainulabdeen, had neither much formal education nor much wealth; despite these disadvantages, he possessed great innate wisdom and a true generosity of spirit. He had an ideal helpmate in my mother, Ashiamma. I do not recall the exact number of people she fed every day, but I am quite certain that far more outsiders ate with us than all the members of our own family put together. 
I was one of many children — a short boy with rather undistinguished looks, born to tall and handsome parents. We lived in our ancestral house, which was built in the middle of the nineteenth century. It was a fairly large pucca house, made of limestone and brick, on Mosque Street in Rameswaram. My austere father used to avoid all inessential comforts and luxuries. However, all necessities were provided for, in terms of food, medicine or clothes. In fact, I would say mine was a very secure childhood, both materially and emotionally. 
The Second World War broke out in 1939, when I was eight years old. For reasons I have never been able to understand, a sudden demand for tamarind seeds erupted in the market. I used to collect the seeds and sell them to a provision shop on Mosque Street. A day’s collection would fetch me the princely sum of one anna. My brother-in-law Jallaluddin would tell me stories about the War which I would later attempt to trace in the headlines of Dinamani. Our area, being isolated, was completely unaffected by the war. But soon India was forced to join the Allied Forces and something like a state of emergency was declared. The first casualty came in the form of the suspension of the train halt at Rameswaram station. The newspapers now had to be bundled and thrown out from the moving train on the Rameswaram Road between Rameswaram and Dhanuskodi. That forced my cousin Samsuddin, who distributed newspapers in Rameswaram, to look for a helping hand to catch the bundles and, as if naturally, I filled the slot. Samsuddin helped me earn my first wages. Half a century later, I can still feel the surge of pride in earning my own money for the first time. 
Every child is born, with some inherited characteristics, into a specific socio-economic and emotional environment, and trained in certain ways by figures of authority. I inherited honesty and self-discipline from my father; from my mother, I inherited faith in goodness and deep kindness and so did my three brothers and sister. I had three close friends in my childhood — Ramanadha Sastry, Aravindan and Sivaprakasan. 
My Childhood - A.P.J Abdul Kalam

The first casualty came in the form of the suspension of the train halt at Rameswaram station. The newspapers now had to be bundled and thrown out from the moving train on the Rameswaram Road between Rameswaram and Dhanuskodi. That forced my cousin Samsuddin, who distributed newspapers in Rameswaram, to look for a helping hand to catch the bundles and, as if naturally, I filled the slot. Samsuddin helped me earn my first wages. Half a century later, I can still feel the surge of pride in earning my own money for the first time. 
Every child is born, with some inherited characteristics, into a specific socio-economic and emotional environment, and trained in certain ways by figures of authority. I inherited honesty and self-discipline from my father; from my mother, I inherited faith in goodness and deep kindness and so did my three brothers and sister. I had three close friends in my childhood — Ramanadha Sastry, Aravindan and Sivaprakasan. 
My Childhood - A.P.J Abdul Kalam

props.summary:
### **Exam Summary: Qualifier Level English (Computer-Based Exam)**
This exam tests **English language proficiency** with a focus on:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Passage-based questions)
2. **Grammar & Syntax** (Voice, tenses, question tags, phrasal verbs, modals, articles)
3. **Vocabulary** (Synonyms, antonyms, word meanings)
4. **Parts of Speech** (Nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs)
5. **Writing Skills** (Formal email drafting)

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension**
- **Key Skills**:
  - Extracting explicit details (e.g., birthplace, materials, historical context).
  - Inferring meanings of words (e.g., *erstwhile* = "former").
  - Identifying true/false statements based on the passage.
- **Passage Analyzed**:
  - Autobiographical excerpt from *My Childhood* by **A.P.J. Abdul Kalam**.
  - Themes: Family, childhood, socio-economic background, World War II impact.

#### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
| **Topic**               | **Key Concepts**                                                                 | **Examples from Questions**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Active/Passive Voice** | Subject performs (active) or receives (passive) the action.                     | *"The engineer constructed this house."* (Active)                                            |
| **Tenses**              | Present Perfect: Actions completed at an unspecified time or continuing.       | *"She has lived here all her life."* (Present Perfect)                                       |
| **Question Tags**       | Short questions added to statements (e.g., *isn’t it?*, *shall we?*).         | *"Let’s go for a hunt, **shall we**?"*                                                       |
| **Modals**              | *Can* (ability), *could* (past ability), *would* (hypothetical).                | *"It **can** be done, for I have done it before."*                                           |
| **Articles**            | *A* (consonant sounds), *an* (vowel sounds), *the* (specific).                   | *"I am **an** English teacher."*                                                              |
| **Phrasal Verbs**       | Multi-word verbs (e.g., *put up with*, *pick on*).                            | *"The teacher could not **put up with** the students’ tardiness."* (Tolerate)                |
| **Sentence Structure**  | Correct adjective/noun forms (e.g., *challenging* vs. *challengeful*).       | *"That is quite a **challenging** task."* (Correct)                                          |

#### **3. Vocabulary**
| **Word**       | **Meaning**                          | **Antonym/Synonym**               |
|----------------|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| Erstwhile      | Former                               | Synonym: *Previous*               |
| Austere        | Simple, without luxury               | Antonym: *Lavish*                 |
| Cruelty        | Harshness                            | Antonym: *Goodness*               |
| Pick on        | Bully/harass                         | Synonym: *Target*                 |
| Pucca          | Permanent (Indian English)           | Antonym: *Temporary*              |

#### **4. Parts of Speech**
| **Word**       | **Part of Speech** | **Example Sentence**                     |
|----------------|--------------------|------------------------------------------|
| Patience       | Noun               | *"Jenny lacks the **patience** to wait."* |
| Small          | Adjective          | *"I have a **small** cat."*              |

#### **5. Writing Skills (Email Drafting)**
- **Structure**:
  1. **Subject Line**: Clear and concise (e.g., *"Acceptance of Graduate School Offer"*).
  2. **Salutation**: Formal (e.g., *"Dear Admissions Committee,"*).
  3. **Body**:
     - Express gratitude.
     - Confirm acceptance.
     - Outline academic plans (e.g., research focus, courses).
  4. **Closing**: Polite (e.g., *"Sincerely, [Name]"*).
- **Example Outline**:
  > *"I am honored to accept the offer to join [Program Name]. My academic plan includes specializing in [Field] with a focus on [Research Topic]. I look forward to contributing to [Specific Project/Club]."*

---

### **Key Equations/Rules (Grammar)**
1. **Active vs. Passive Voice**:
   - **Active**: Subject + Verb + Object (*She wrote a letter.*).
   - **Passive**: Object + *be* + Past Participle + *by* Subject (*A letter was written by her.*).

2. **Present Perfect Tense**:
   - **Structure**: Subject + *has/have* + Past Participle (*She has lived here*).

3. **Question Tags**:
   - **Rule**: If the statement is positive, the tag is negative (*You are coming, **aren’t you**?*).

4. **Articles**:
   - *A* before consonant sounds (*a cat*), *an* before vowel sounds (*an apple*).

5. **Modals for Ability**:
   - *Can* (present), *Could* (past), *Will be able to* (future).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Grammar & Syntax Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[English Grammar] --> B[Tenses]
    A --> C[Voice]
    A --> D[Modals]
    A --> E[Articles]
    A --> F[Question Tags]
    A --> G[Phrasal Verbs]

    B --> B1[Present Perfect]
    B --> B2[Past Simple]
    C --> C1[Active Voice]
    C --> C2[Passive Voice]
    D --> D1[Can]
    D --> D2[Could]
    E --> E1[A/An/The]
    F --> F1[Shall we?]
    G --> G1[Put up with]
    G --> G2[Pick on]
```

#### **2. Reading Comprehension & Vocabulary**
```mermaid
graph TD
    H[Reading Comprehension] --> I[Passage Analysis]
    H --> J[Vocabulary]
    I --> I1[Explicit Details]
    I --> I2[Inference]
    J --> J1[Synonyms]
    J --> J2[Antonyms]
    J --> J3[Phrasal Verbs]

    I1 --> I1a[Birthplace: Rameswaram]
    I1 --> I1b[House Material: Limestone]
    J1 --> J1a[Erstwhile = Former]
    J2 --> J2a[Cruelty ≠ Goodness]
    J3 --> J3a[Pick on = Bully]
```

#### **3. Parts of Speech**
```mermaid
graph TD
    K[Parts of Speech] --> L[Noun]
    K --> M[Verb]
    K --> N[Adjective]
    K --> O[Adverb]

    L --> L1[Patience]
    M --> M1[Lacks]
    N --> N1[Small]
    O --> O1[Quickly]
```

#### **4. Writing Skills**
```mermaid
graph TD
    P[Formal Email] --> Q[Structure]
    Q --> Q1[Subject Line]
    Q --> Q2[Salutation]
    Q --> Q3[Body]
    Q --> Q4[Closing]

    Q3 --> Q3a[Gratitude]
    Q3 --> Q3b[Acceptance]
    Q3 --> Q3c[Academic Plan]
```

---
### **Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Practice summarizing passages and identifying key details.
   - Learn context-based vocabulary (e.g., *pucca*, *austere*).

2. **Grammar**:
   - Memorize rules for tenses, voice, and question tags.
   - Practice transforming sentences (e.g., active → passive).

3. **Vocabulary**:
   - Maintain a list of synonyms/antonyms (e.g., *goodness* vs. *cruelty*).
   - Learn common phrasal verbs (*put up with*, *pick on*).

4. **Writing**:
   - Draft a template for formal emails (acceptance, inquiries).
   - Focus on clarity and conciseness (200-word limit).

5. **Parts of Speech**:
   - Identify nouns/verbs/adjectives in sentences (e.g., *patience* = noun).
